In a government announcement on the 9th of December, it was announced that all educational establishments across Estonia will be closed until 2021.   In person learning is allowed for students with special educational needs, personal consultations, olympiads, internships and examinations with measures of social distancing in place.   Kindergartens and childcare will remain open.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201209134400/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-additional-restrictions-both-ida-viru-county-and-across-estonia-prevent

The government approved the extension of the current education restrictions to and including the 10th of January.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

From the 5th of December, there may be no more than 50% capacity of a given space in indoor sales areas and public spaces of stores and service areas. People must also adhere to the 2+2 rule.    From the 5th of December, catering and educational establishments and locations for holding public events where a stationary seat is not ensured to all attendees must close from 22:00 to 6:00. Takeaway food is permitted to operate during these hours.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201206171931/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/government-adopted-further-restrictions-prevent-spread-coronavirus

From the 12th of December, in Ida-Viru County, entertainment and accommodation facilities, museums and exhibitions must be closed to visitors. All sports facilities must be closed. This does not apply to professional sports activities. All sales and service halls of catering companies must be closed. Food takeaway and related courier service will be allowed.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201210173303/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-approved-new-national-restrictions-and-restrictions-ida-viru-county

Restrictions are expanded in Harju County and Ida-Viru County from the 28th of December. All entertainment services must close. All catering company premises are closed to customers, however food takeaway and delivery services are permitted. All sports facilities must be closed to visitors. However this does not apply to professional athletes or those with special needs.   Indoor youth work, hobby activities, further education/informal education is no longer permitted.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

From the 12th of December in the Ida-Viru County, both outdoor and indoor public meetings and events, including conferences, theatre performances, concerts, and cinema screenings are not allowed.   Churches and other religious venues may continue to operate at 50% capacity with 2+2 distancing.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201210173303/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-approved-new-national-restrictions-and-restrictions-ida-viru-county

In Harju County and Ida-Viru County, public meetings and events are prohibited. This includes conferences, theatre performances, indoor cinema viewing, museum and exhibition viewing.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

From the 14th of December, hobby education, hobby activities and sports activities for young people and adults will be suspended for three weeks. Only individual activities/learning/sports offered remotely or outdoors are allowed.   The restrictions do not apply to professional athletes.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201209134400/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-additional-restrictions-both-ida-viru-county-and-across-estonia-prevent

From the 24th of December, a 50% of maximum capacity requirement for religious services will apply nationally.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

In Harju County and Ida-Viru Count, from the 28th of December a maximum of 10 people can take part in meetings outdoors.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

The Estonian vaccination drive began on 27th of December. Healthcare workers (group A) are the first to be vaccinated, using the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210101212336/https://news.err.ee/1220851/over-200-health-care-workers-receive-covid-19-vaccination-on-first-day

In Helsinki, institutions of upper secondary education (upper secondary schools and vocational schools) will move to distance learning. The needs for necessary contact teaching will still be secured. Contact teaching will be offered, among other groups, to disabled students receiving special needs education and to students who need individual support for any reason. Distance learning will begin at the start of the new evaluation period on 3 December 2020 and continue until 31 December 2020.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201221175327/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/coronavirus-en/childhood-and    In the rest of the country, schools remain open but with social distancing measures in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201221175732/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/questions-and-answers

In Helsinki, upper secondary schools (general upper secondary schools and vocational education) have transferred to distance learning as of 3 December 2020. These learning institutions will still provide face-to-face instruction that is deemed essential. For example, contact teaching will be offered to students with disabilities that are receiving special needs education and to students who need individual support for various reasons. Distance learning will continue at these schools until 10 January 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104175356/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/coronavirus-en/childhood-and    In the rest of the country, schools remain open but with social distancing measures in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104175432/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/questions-and-answers

The government recommends working from home. Restaurants and shops are open with social distancing measures and restrictions on alcohol sales in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104175432/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/questions-and-answers

The strictest regional policy is that public events and gatherings are only allowed up to 10 people, which means that, in practice, public events are not able to take place.     Overview of the dates of the regulation currently still in force:    Helsinki and Uusimaa, 30.11.2020-10.1.2021  Päijät-Häme, 30.11.2020-4.1.2021  Kanta-Häme, 1.12.2020-10.1.2021.   Kymenlaakso, 1.12.2020-10.1.2021  Länsi-Pohja, 7.12.2020-18.1.2021   Varsinais-Suomi, 11.12.2020-10.1.2021  Pirkanmaa  and Punkalaidunta: 2.12.2020-17.1.2021   Central Finland, Southern Ostrobothnia, Central Ostrobothnia and Vaasa: 22.12.2020-17.1.2021  Northern Ostrobothnia: 2.12.2020-18.1.2021    At the national level, public meetings and general meetings of more than 50 people can be organized in limited areas outdoors and indoors if the events follow the government's social distancing guidelines.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104175739/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta

There is no policy for private events, but several regional authorities recommend that people adhere to the regional guidelines for (public) indoor gatherings in private as well. I have therefore coded this as 4, since at the regional level, indoor gatherings are restricted to max 10 people (see also the note under C3).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104175739/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta

Travel within Finland is allowed as long as health and safety guidelines relating to coronavirus are observed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221180827/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions

According to the government FAQ:     Is travel within Finland allowed?    Travel within Finland is allowed as long as health and safety guidelines relating to coronavirus are observed.    All travel must be avoided when ill. During travel, it is important to observe good hand and respiratory hygiene. It is important to avoid unnecessary physical contact Tourism businesses must pay particular attention to cleaning, preparedness planning and training of staff.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104175432/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/questions-and-answers

No change in policy. On 10 December, the Government decided to extend the restrictions on entry into the country until 12 January 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221180827/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions

Non-Schengen: Entry into Finland is restricted. Return travel and essential traffic are permitted. These measures will remain in force until 12 January 2012.     Schengen: Restrictions on internal border traffic are in force for traffic between Finland and Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland, with the exception of leisure boating.    Restrictions have been lifted for traffic arriving in Finland from the Vatican, and for traffic between Finland and Australia, Japan, Rwanda, South Korea, Singapore, Thailand and New Zealand for residents of these countries.    A 10-day period of self-isolation is recommended for travellers arriving in Finland. Travellers can shorten their self-isolation period at their discretion if they take two voluntary COVID-19 tests.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104182727/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/entry-restrictions

Mask use is never mandatory, but now recommended extensively. In the regions where the infection rates are highest, in the so-called "spreading phase" (according to the Finnish classification of regions into 3 types: basic, accelleration, spreading), the recommendation includes:   - Always on public transport including taxis.  - Always in public spaces and events, including schools and educational institutions from year 7 upwards.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221193557/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/recommendation-on-the-use-of-face-masks-for-citizens

Finland’s priority is to immunise the whole population once a safe and effective vaccine is approved for use in the EU."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221191413/https://stm.fi/en/coronavirus-vaccines

Finland's vaccination campaign started on 27 December, with front-line ICU healthcare workers in Helsinki being the first recipients of the vaccine.     Vaccination takes place according to vaccine priority groups. These are:   1) healthcare and social welfare workers who examine or directly treat and care for patients with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 disease or who provide other kinds of urgent care, and workers and residents in care homes for older adults;  2) all those 70 years of age and older;   3) persons at high risk for severe COVID-19 disease due to underlying health conditions;   4) other persons than those in priority groups 1–3.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104183537/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/1271139/healthcare-and-social-welfare-workers-first-in-line-to-get-authorised-covid-19-vaccines-on-voluntary-basis

Stay out after 8pm - there is a strict 8pm to 6am curfew and only in exceptional circumstances are you allowed out at night. If you are out, you will need an attestation permission form - full details on the rules here. The curfew is lifted on December 24th - the main day for family celebrations in France - but not on New Year's Eve.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201222023746/https://www.thelocal.fr/20201217/what-can-you-do-in-france-over-christmas-and-new-year-under-covid-19-rules

A curfew from 8pm to 6am remains in place nationwide. In addition, from 2nd January 2021, the curfew is extended to 6pm to 6am for the following departements: Hautes-Alpes, Alpes-Maritimes, Ardennes, Doubs, Jura, Marne, Haute-Marne, Meurthe-et-Moselle, Meuse, Nièvre, Haute-Saône, Saône-et-Loire, Vosges, Territoire de Belfort and Moselle.    https://archive.vn/Oj35M#selection-1061.1-1061.518

The following policies have been announced on 15 Dec:    Travel to other bits of France - travel for any reason between regions is now allowed and there is no need for the attestation permission form on trips. There are no limits on staying with friends or family, in holiday rentals or in hotels.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201222023746/https://www.thelocal.fr/20201217/what-can-you-do-in-france-over-christmas-and-new-year-under-covid-19-rules
There are no restrictions for traveling within France.    https://archive.vn/jGRh1#selection-2541.0-2541.54
No policy change

Ban for non-EU countries    Travel in or out of France - likewise international travel for non-essential reasons is now allowed. Entry to France is possible from all EU and Schengen zone countries. This includes the UK until December 31st, but after that travellers from the UK may be restricted again. There is no need to quarantine or be tested in advance when entering France, although airports and some train stations now have testing facilities in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201222023746/https://www.thelocal.fr/20201217/what-can-you-do-in-france-over-christmas-and-new-year-under-covid-19-rules

Complete travel ban from the UK to France on the 21st and 22nd of December in order to contain the new Coronavirus mutation:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201222025255/https://www.thelocal.fr/20201221/frances-uk-travel-ban-who-is-affected-and-what-happens-next

No policy changes. Current situation in more detail:    •	Broad restrictions on non-essential travel from many countries outside the European Union, including the United States, remain in place. The French government has defined essential travel as entry by French citizens, residents of France, all foreign (including United States citizen) students (with appropriate visa or residence permit), and spouses and children of French citizens.  •	In rare cases, the French government will consider allowing travel in humanitarian situations and in cases of business activity important to the French economy, and have announced a program to allow unmarried couples to reunite.    https://archive.vn/jGRh1#selection-2331.0-2331.47    •	France announced they would be restricting travel from the UK from 00:00 (CET) on 20 December. Travel restriction apply to all air, car, ferry and train passengers. If you are due to travel to France please contact your travel operator. Until at least 6 January, only the following categories of people will be authorised to travel to France from the UK:  1.	French nationals and nationals of the European Area and their spouses and children  2.	British and/or third country nationals who are either habitually resident in France, the European Union or the European Area, or who must travel for certain essential reasons (as specified by the French government)  3.	British or third country nationals travelling for certain exceptional reasons, see the French Embassy London’s list.  •	All travellers from the UK, including children aged 11 and above, will need to present a negative COVID-19 test result, carried out less than 72 hours before departure  •	Please check our COVID-19 advice on things to consider, and be prepared to stay overseas longer than planned  •	Although there is no restriction on travel from most European countries, travel from most non-European countries is subject to entry restrictions  •	Arrivals from the UK will need to complete both a ‘sworn statement’ (déclaration sur l’honneur) form self-certifying they are not suffering from symptoms associated with coronavirus and have not been in contact with confirmed cases in the preceding fortnight, and a signed ‘travel certificate’ (attestation), confirming their reason for travel. These can be found on the French government’s website.    https://archive.vn/3mbzC

Take off your mask - masks are compulsory in all enclosed public spaces in France while around 400 local authorities - which includes all the major cities - have also made masks compulsory in the street.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201222023746/https://www.thelocal.fr/20201217/what-can-you-do-in-france-over-christmas-and-new-year-under-covid-19-rules

A growing number of French cities now require cloth face coverings in outdoor areas throughout or in designated parts of the city. This includes Paris and its suburbs, where cloth face coverings are required in all outdoor locations. Rules vary by city and can change quickly. Check with the website of each city.    https://archive.vn/jGRh1#selection-2691.0-2691.312    Additional details about mask requirements in and around Paris are listed on this page:  https://archive.vn/0NTc9#selection-2679.0-2679.45

No availability yet but plans in place to start vaccination in January. Vaccination will be rolled out in three phases:    Phase 1: January 2021 – elderly care home residents, and residence staff who are at risk of developing severe illness (about one million people)  Phase 2: February 2021 -  people who are at risk of developing severe illness, and health care workers – about 14 million people.  Phase 3: spring 2021 – availability for the entire population, although still prioritized e.g. by age.  Vaccination will be free and voluntary.    https://archive.vn/aLCoS
PARIS (Reuters) - France will start its COVID-19 vaccination programme next Sunday, Health Minister Olivier Veran wrote on his Twitter feed.  https://archive.vn/HrrMw

As of Dec. 31, only 352 people had gotten at least one dose of the vaccine, versus 131,626 in Germany and 944,539 in the U.K., according to data cited by Le Parisien.  https://archive.vn/0E17Q    From 2nd January, people over 50 will begin to be vaccinated (which had previously been planned for February), to speed up the vaccination roll out.  https://archive.vn/R00XW

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    Retailers at Christmas: Businesses should ensure that hand sanitiser is readily available and that stores are kept clean. Signs should be clearly displayed to help customers keep to the recommendations. Staff should use protective gear where necessary. Retailers can help by making face masks available for customers. If retailers cannot limit the number of customers so that the recommended distances can be maintained, then both customers and staff are advised to wear face masks.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    · Sport: All indoor sporting events should be held without spectators. This applies to both adult and children’s competitions. Coaches and assistants can be present during matches.    · Schools and daycare centres are advised not to hold larger events to which people from outside the institution are usually invited. This includes Christmas celebrations which would normally be attended by parents and other family members. Christmas church services for school pupils and preschool children should not be organised as usual this year      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    · Schools and daycare centres are advised not to hold larger events to which people from outside the institution are usually invited. This includes Christmas celebrations which would normally be attended by parents and other family members. Christmas church services for school pupils and preschool children should not be organised as usual this year.    · Christmas shopping: Special emphasis should be placed on social distancing hand and hygiene and. It is advisable that only one person in the household does the shopping, rather than going several together. It is also advisable to go shopping when there are fewer people.  Face masks are recommended when a lot of people are in a shop. If you have come to the Faroe Islands from abroad, you should not go shopping at all until you have received a negative result from the test that you should take 6 days after arrival.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

3rd December 2020 Mandatory testing of travellers at the borders will be extended until 31 March, the epidemic commission announced today.     https://web.archive.org/save/https://corona.fo/news/734/mandatory-border-testing-continues-until-31-march

11. December 2020, Test center opening hours are scheduled. Testing is free of charge.     Those wishing to be tested in Klaksvík, Tórshavn and Tvøroyri are required to pre-register here or book a time slot on 304545. Telephone opening hours are Monday to Friday 14pm to 16pm.  Once registered, people receive a notification by phone and email, which they are asked to show on arrival.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201215105712/https://corona.fo/news/675/test-center-opening-hours?_l=en

Under Tier 4 restrictions, you must stay at home, and you must not leave your home to travel unless for essential work, education, or other legally permitted reasons    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221220916/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-safer-travel-guidance-for-passengers

Scots are to be ordered to stay at home amid a fresh Covid-19 lockdown on 5 January. These are the toughest restrictions Scotland has faced since the lockdown of March 2020.      The new rules - which will be put down in law - mean Scots will only be allowed to leave home for essential purposes, such as shopping for food and medicine, exercise and caring responsibilities.    No limit is to be put on how many times people can go out to exercise, but outdoor meetings are to be limited to a maximum of two people from two households.      These rules will apply across the Scottish mainland until at least the end of January, and will be kept under review.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104154939/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-55531069

Under tier 4 restrictions, people cannot leave home for holidays or stays overnight away from their main home unless permitted by law.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221220916/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-safer-travel-guidance-for-passengers

Face masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, including taxis and public transportation. Violators of face musk rules are subject to a 20 GEL (about 6 USD) fine. There are some exceptions for children under 6, people with disabilities, or who have health problems that prevent them from wearing a face covering.  Link: Measures to control the spread of COVID-19 in Georgia | U.S. Embassy in Georgia (archive.fo)

From 7 December 2020 through 14 December 2020, all schools (including higher education institutions) are physically closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201209182307/https://covid19.gov.gr/leitourgia-scholeion-pasis-fysis-ekpaideftikon-domon-aei-kai-choron-latreias-gia-to-diastima-apo-ti-deftera-7-dekemvriou-2020-kai-ora-600-eos-kai-ti-deftera-14-dekemvriou-2020-kai-ora-600-2/

Greek authorities have re-imposed a lockdown through January 7, 2021 to combat the spread of COVID-19. Authorities announced 24-hour movement restrictions, mandatory three day quarantine for travelers arriving from abroad, an expanded nighttime curfew, suspension of many business and entertainment operations, prohibition of gatherings, restrictions of restaurant operations to delivery/carry-out only, and restrictions on travel between regions in Greece.   https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No policy change

Greek authorities have re-imposed a lockdown through January 7, 2021 to combat the spread of COVID-19. Authorities announced 24-hour movement restrictions, mandatory three day quarantine for travelers arriving from abroad, an expanded nighttime curfew, suspension of many business and entertainment operations, prohibition of gatherings, restrictions of restaurant operations to delivery/carry-out only, and restrictions on travel between regions in Greece.   https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    No more than nine people (from two households) should gather in the same house, in order to avoid overcrowding.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://greekcitytimes.com/2020/12/14/christmas-covid19-rules-greece/
No policy change

Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks are required while using public transportation and taxis. Taxis are limited to one passenger, except for minor children.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No policy change

Movement Restrictions:  Is a curfew in place? Yes  A nationwide lockdown is in effect 24 hours per day through January 7, 2021.  A nighttime curfew is additionally in effect from 10:00pm to 5:00am.  In general, travel outside the home should be avoided, but is permitted for work and for the following reasons between the hours of 5:00am and 10:00pm:  For health reasons;  To buy essential supplies if delivery is not possible in time;  Essential banking or urgent appointments for public services (e.g., electricity);  To help people in need. Transfer to/from workplace of a spouse or first-degree relative. Transfer of a minor to/from school (with a certificate from the school);  Attending a ceremony (e.g., funeral). Travel to exercise visitation rights;  Movements near one’s residence for physical exercise, or care of pets or strays  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    All individuals residing in Greece will be required to send an SMS text message to 13033 in order to obtain permission to leave their homes during the lockdown.    The SMS to 13033 should be formatted as follows: X (one of the digits 1-6 corresponding to the activities below), name, surname and address. https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://greekcitytimes.com/2020/12/14/christmas-covid19-rules-greece/
No policy change

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes  As of November 7, 2020,  travel between other regions in Greece is allowed only for health reasons, business, family reunification, or to return to one’s place of permanent residence and requires declaration as described at forma.gov.gr/en.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No policy change

Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? No  Greece will currently only allow EU citizens, EU residents, and residents of certain other specific countries to enter. The United States is not one of those countries.  U.S. citizens traveling to Greece will not be permitted to enter unless they meet one of only a few narrow exceptions detailed in the Greek Embassy’s information on entrance into the European Union/Schengen Area.  There is no projected date when entry will be permitted.  A long visit in a third country will not help you get around EU restrictions.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Those entering Greece from abroad between December 18 and January 7 must observe a mandatory three-day quarantine. https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://greekcitytimes.com/2020/12/14/christmas-covid19-rules-greece/
No policy change

COVID-19 tests are available at many major hospitals in Greece, as well as the Athens Eleftherios Venizelos Airport (at Arrivals level between entrances 2-3). Testing is paid by the individual being tested.  The average cost for COVID-19 testing is 100-120 euros. Patients needing COVID-19 tests or exhibiting possible symptoms may contact the COVID-19 hotline at 1135 for guidance on testing and referral for medical care.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Vaccines are not yet being administered, but there is a government-funded policy in place:    Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis met with advisors and government ministers virtually on Saturday 5 December 20202 in order to discuss the country’s Covid-19 vaccination plan.    Reportedly, vaccinations will begin in January, with healthcare workers having priority. Greeks will be able to make appointments to receive the free shot at one of the country’s 1,018 vaccination centers that are currently being created in order to best distribute the vaccine to as many people as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201209210724/https://greece.greekreporter.com/2020/12/05/greece-to-begin-covid-19-vaccinations-in-january-1383-new-cases-saturday/
No noted updates  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Vaccinations will take place based on priority groups.  Following the vaccination of frontline healthcare workers and vulnerable groups that have priority, the vaccinations of the general population will begin some time during the second ten days of January 2021.  Citizens who wish to get vaccinated will be able to book an appointment online on the e-platform https://emvolio.gov.gr/ (currently under construction and cannot be accessed).  Since there are currently no clinical trials in pregnant women and children, these populations are excluded from vaccination at this stage.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210103143553/https://eody.gov.gr/erotiseis-kai-apantiseis-schetika-me-ton-emvoliasmo-gia-ton-koronoio-sars-cov-2/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210103143655/https://news.gtp.gr/2020/12/21/greece-announces-when-general-population-will-receive-covid-19-vaccine/

The latest update remains that there is an executive order in place, until and including the 31st January 2021, which states:  “It is possible to hold public events within current municipal boundaries with certain restrictions. It is the organizer's responsibility to ensure that there is no participation from people from other municipalities, or that this is encouraged.  Courses can still be run with external teachers, as long as the participants are from the same municipality.”  “There must be a maximum of 100 people for an indoor event, provided that the rules on occupancy in the room itself of a maximum of 50% of what is allowed are also complied with. For outdoor events, there can be a maximum of 250 people.”    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221150605/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/forsamlinger_i_groenland?sc_lang=da

On December 19, economic protections are extended until 01 July.  According to this, the moratorium on loan repayments for families and businesses will be extended unchanged for six months until 1 July. The moratorium will be automatically extended, only those who want to repay their loan despite the moratorium will have to visit their bank, the Prime Minister said.  It also announced that businesses forced to close temporarily as a a cause of disease measures would be supported by the government in December and January by waived and taking over two-thirds of wage costs. In addition to catering, hotels and tourism, the remission of contributions and wage subsidies will be extended to private bus companies that are forced to take a break.  Viktor Orban also said that business taxes for small and medium-sized enterprises and sole proprietors will be cut by half from 1 January. These businesses account for the most jobs and are the most vulnerable during the epidemic, he justified the measure, adding that municipalities of less than 25,000 inhabitants will receive support from the government and the financial situation of larger municipalities will be reviewed individually.  The fourth decision is to help families with children and children with a reduced home improvement loan of up to HUF 6 million with a maximum interest rate of 3 percent. Of this, HUF 3 million is a non-refundable grant, which can be used at the end of the renovation and automatically reduces the amount of the loan, the Prime Minister explained.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219210422/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/orban-viktor-kormany-gazdasagvedelmi-akcioterv-kiegesziteserol-rendelkezett

The Hungarian government has started a COVID-19 vaccine registration at vakcinainfo.gov.hu in order to estimate how many people are interested in the vaccine. Although a vaccine is still not available, the Russian vaccine and its documentation are being examined, and the documentation of the Chinese vaccine will soon arrive in Hungary.     https://archive.vn/y5lyf

On 18 December, it was announced that vaccinations against the coronavirus can begin on 27 or 28 December, in the first round a sufficient amount will arrive in Hungary for 35,000 people, and health workers will be vaccinated in the first place, Prime Minister Viktor Orban announced on Kossuth radio's Good Morning, Hungary! on his show. Vaccination will be voluntary and free of charge.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219205730/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/orban-december-27-28-kezdodhetnek-az-elso-oltasok

School closure - the final day of term. Schools do not close early for Christmas     https://web.archive.org/web/20201228195617/https://www.irishtimes.com/news/education/covid-19-schools-will-not-close-early-for-christmas-norma-foley-1.4439735

From Friday 4th December, restaurants and pubs that serve substantial meals may reopen for indoor dining. There will be a limit of six people per table, but no limit to the number of households that they may come from.  Wet pubs may only provide delivery and takeaway services while, nightclubs and casinos will remain closed.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210104201105/https://www.rte.ie/news/coronavirus/2020/1127/1180966-virus-restrictions-christmas/

Organised events can take place in Ireland as long as these are controlled environments with a named event organiser, owner or manager.  Gatherings of up to 15 people can take place. Face coverings are recommended in busy or crowded areas.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214192520/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/ad569-level-3/
On Tuesday up to 50 people can gather at places of worship     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104201105/https://www.rte.ie/news/coronavirus/2020/1127/1180966-virus-restrictions-christmas/

From Friday 18th December, the Government is allowing three households to mix for social and family gatherings in homes, gardens and other outdoor settings.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104201105/https://www.rte.ie/news/coronavirus/2020/1127/1180966-virus-restrictions-christmas/
From 4th December public transport capacity limited to 50%.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214192520/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/ad569-level-3/

Recommended to stay in your county apart from work, education, medical and other essential purposes, if appropriate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214192520/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/ad569-level-3/

On 18th December internal movement is permitted.  These restrictions will allow people to travel around the country for two weeks, until 6th January.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104201105/https://www.rte.ie/news/coronavirus/2020/1127/1180966-virus-restrictions-christmas/

On 22 December the Irish Government extended its ban on flights and passenger ferry journeys from Great Britain until at least 31 December. This applies to people in Great Britain regardless of nationality. Ferry crossings from Great Britain to Ireland will continue for freight, including accompanied freight, but not passengers, although ferry journeys from Ireland to Great Britain are open to both freight and passengers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228200145/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ireland/entry-requirements

The Irish Government announced additional flexibility for self-employed workers on the scheme was announced. Self-employed people in receipt of the PUP who are looking to restart their business can now earn up to €960 over an 8 week period, while retaining their full PUP entitlement. This is an increase from the €480 previously allowed over a 4 week period and comes following engagement across a number of sectors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214193900/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/43e6e-briefing-on-the-governments-response-to-covid-19-friday-11-december-2020/

Restrictions have been updated although coding remains the same.  Performing arts, cinema theatres and other cultural events may have up to 30 persons on stage, i.e. during rehearsals and shows. Up to 50 seated guests may be accommodated. Such guests must wear face masks. In addition, 100 children born in 2005 or later may be accommodated. Seats are to be numbered and labelled with the name of the guest. Neither breaks nor alcohol sales are permitted.  Restaurants may be open until 22:00 on all days but must comply with the 15-person limit rule and the 2-metre proximity limit between unrelated persons. Take-away meals may be served after 22:00.  Pharmacies, grocery stores and other stores may accept 5 persons for each 10 m2 of space and may have up to 100 customers in their premises, as long as it is possible to ensure at least 2 metres between persons who are unrelated.    Swimming pools are open and may accept up to 50% of their maximum number of guests according to their operating permit.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201213162115/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/what-is-ban-on-public-events

Restrictions have been updated to make exceptions in certain circumstances.  At funerals, up to 50 persons may attend, while general restrictions apply to funeral receptions, i.e. 10 persons.  Sports activities for persons born 2004 or earlier are permitted, whether with or without physical contact, in sports organised by ÍSÍ in male and female top divisions in each discipline. The maximum number of participants in each location is 25.  The training of top athletes in individual-orientated sports within ÍSÍ are permitted with the caveat that the number of persons in each area is a maximum of 25.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201213162115/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/what-is-ban-on-public-events

Particular importance will be placed on vaccinating persons who are in the frontline in the battle against the pandemic. This applies to healthcare workers and others working in emergency departments and intensive care units in hospitals, on COVID-19 wards and wards for patients who have been infected with COVID-19, healthcare workers who perform screening tests in cases of suspected COVID-19 and the staff of nursing and retirement homes. The vaccination of persons living in nursing and retirement homes and old-age wards in hospitals will also have high priority.    There are ten priority groups. The groups with the greatest priority consist of a relatively few number of people; the first five groups are estimated to number around 20,000 persons.    Group 6: Persons aged 60 and older    Group 7: Persons with underlying long-term illnesses    Group 8: Employees of nursery, primary and secondary schools and select groups of social and welfare service workers    Group 9: Persons who are in sensitive circumstances due to their social and economic situation    And finally, Group 10: All others who request vaccination, as determined by the Chief Epidemiologist.    The regulation makes no provision for the COVID-19 vaccination of children born 2006 or later unless such children have an underlying long-term illness and are members of a special risk group.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210103140447/https://www.covid.is/categories/information-on-covid-19-vaccine

A total of 1,843 schools across the country have resumed in-person classes. Schools were opened based on the epidemiological situation in each city and village. The government is preparing to strictly control the epidemiological situation during the campaign period.   Links: https://archive.vn/9pUdF

The government has delegated the responsibility of deciding on detailed restrictions on public gatherings to local authorities, based on their respective epidemiological profiles. However, the Deputy Prime Minister announced that corporate New Year's parties will be banned. He did not state an upper limit to the gathering size. A presidential election and referendum will be held on 10 Jan 2021. The government has developed social distancing protocols for election procedures. Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    Primary, pre-secondary and secondary education will be provided remotely, except special needs schools and special needs classes in general education schools following the programmes of primary, pre-secondary, individualised primary and pre-secondary education, and secondary education, programmes of development of social skills;    Pre-school, pre-primary education will be provided following the conditions laid down by the Commander of Operations’ decision, in-person pre-school and pre-primary education is recommended only for those children whose parents (adoptive parents or guardians) have no possibilities of working remotely.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

Update on 2nd of December:    "Government approves tighter lockdown rules.    The adverse epidemic coronavirus (COVID-19) situation in Lithuania has necessitated further tightening of the lockdown rules by restricting the size of gatherings, banning the operation of temporary vendors in malls and supermarkets. It has also been recommended to discontinue short-term sales promotion measures to bring down visitor flows.    The Government has agreed to ban the operation of temporary vendors in shops, supermarkets and points of service, where sales are not made in physically separated premises but in common areas and passageways of malls and supermarkets. Exceptions apply to selling foodstuffs, pyrotechnic items and also to fixed vending stalls."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210091436/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/government-approves-tighter-lockdown-rules

Update on 2nd of December (coming into force on Wednesday, December 9):    "Government approves tighter lockdown rules.    The adverse epidemic coronavirus (COVID-19) situation in Lithuania has necessitated further tightening of the lockdown rules by restricting the size of gatherings, banning the operation of temporary vendors in malls and supermarkets. It has also been recommended to discontinue short-term sales promotion measures to bring down visitor flows.    The Government has agreed to ban the operation of temporary vendors in shops, supermarkets and points of service, where sales are not made in physically separated premises but in common areas and passageways of malls and supermarkets. Exceptions apply to selling foodstuffs, pyrotechnic items and also to fixed vending stalls."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210091436/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/government-approves-tighter-lockdown-rules

Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    State and municipal institutions and bodies and state and municipal enterprises and the private sector will organise work and provide customer services remotely, except where relevant functions (work) have to be performed at the workplace, while ensuring conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for the management of the flow of people, safe physical distance, and other key requirements for public health safety, hygiene, and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment    Stores, including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres, marketplaces and other public points of sale will be closed except:    -stores (including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres), whose main business is the retail of food, veterinary, animal feed, pharmacy, optical goods and orthopedic technical devices;  -selling food in marketplaces and public points of sale;  -remote commerce (by internet or other means of communication), where goods are delivered to natural and legal persons or collected at collection points;  -funeral stores;  -outdoor trade in Christmas trees and other festive trees.    Stores that remain open will be required to:    ensure 15 sq. m. of retail space per visitor or serve only one visitor at a time and ensure other conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

There will be no indoor or outdoor commercial or non-commercial cultural, entertainment, sporting events, celebrations, fairs, festivals or other mass gatherings arranged in public locations of a certain duration at a scheduled time except:    high-performance sporting events without spectators;  funerals attended by maximum 10 persons except family and/or household members and persons providing funeral services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

Update on 2nd of December:    "Government approves tighter lockdown rules.    The adverse epidemic coronavirus (COVID-19) situation in Lithuania has necessitated further tightening of the lockdown rules by restricting the size of gatherings, banning the operation of temporary vendors in malls and supermarkets. It has also been recommended to discontinue short-term sales promotion measures to bring down visitor flows.    The Government has agreed to reduce the size of gatherings from five to two people in public places, points of sale and services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210091436/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/government-approves-tighter-lockdown-rules

Update on 2nd of December (coming into force on Wednesday, December 9):    "Government approves tighter lockdown rules.    The adverse epidemic coronavirus (COVID-19) situation in Lithuania has necessitated further tightening of the lockdown rules by restricting the size of gatherings, banning the operation of temporary vendors in malls and supermarkets. It has also been recommended to discontinue short-term sales promotion measures to bring down visitor flows.    The Government has agreed to reduce the size of gatherings from five to two people in public places, points of sale and services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210091436/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/government-approves-tighter-lockdown-rules

Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    It is allowed to be in public places in groups of no more than 2 persons or in groups of one family and/or one household.   It is prohibited to hold private parties in public and private venues with the participation of more than one family and/or household and to have close contacts between members of more than one family and/or one household except:    -emergencies, where it is necessary to provide assistance;  -attending to the sick or to those unable to take care of themselves;    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    Passengers travelling by public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) will be required to travel seated maintaining the distance of at least one meter between each other. No other restrictions, however.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    It is required to stay at home except:    -to go to work (for work purposes);  -to go shopping;  -to go to/from airports, seaports, bus stations serving international passenger routes;  -to go to your real estate property;  -to go to a funeral;  -for health and other essential services;  -for other essential services or for objectively justified reasons where it is absolutely necessary;  -to go for a walk in open spaces only with members of your family or household;  -to attend to the sick or to those unable to take care of themselves.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

'All passenger flights from the United Kingdom are suspended. The ban will take effect as of 21 December, 04.00, and will last until 31 December, 24.00'    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221151247/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-20-december-2020

Currently, the contact tracing system in Lithuania is overwhelmed. On 3rd December, newly elected Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte told that NVSC failed to do contact tracing for all positve cases. Moreover, the newly elected Minister of Health Arunas Dulkys on 12th December told that the priority at the time was that NVSC could complete contact tracing for all cases within 48 hours after positive test result, indicating that it is not currently done.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201212143139/https://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/lietuvoje/2/1290792/simonyte-kritikuoja-nvsc-del-nepasiruosimo-vasara-jei-istinka-koma-nuo-200-nauju-atveju-akivaizdu-kazkas-neveikia  https://web.archive.org/web/20201212143341/https://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/lietuvoje/2/1296629/dulkys-tikina-kaledoms-atsipalaiduoti-negalima-nereiketu-del-to-apgaudineti-saves

Officials are already stating priorities which is why I decided to code it into here anyways. Later changes might be required.    "The first groups to be vaccinated would include our [Lithuania’s] medics, people in care homes, people in risk groups”, said Sinkevicius (Lithuania’s European Commissioner).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210094732/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1293325/lithuania-may-receive-covid-vaccine-in-3-4-weeks-says-european-commissioner-sinkevicius

Lithuania started vaccinations against COVID-19 on 27th of December:    "Lithuania on Saturday started to vaccinate its medical workers against the coronavirus in a coordinated push by the European Union against the global pandemic.  Nijole Ramonaite, a nurse at Vilnius University Hospital Santaros Klinikos, was the first person in the country inoculated by the vaccine produced by Pfizer and BionTech.  Vaccination was launched in hospitals in Vilnius, Kaunas, Klaipeda, Siauliai and Panevezys simultaneously at 8:00 a.m. on Sunday."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201228154724/https://www.baltictimes.com/lithuania_starts_vaccinations_against_covid-19/    Regarding strategy:  Acting Health Minister Aurelijus Veryga said that medics and at-risk people in the country would be vaccinated from the coronavirus first. If a sufficient amount of vaccines is delivered to Lithuania, mass vaccination of the population could start in February or March, according to Veryga.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228154743/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1296189/most-people-in-lithuania-to-receive-vaccines-by-mid-summer-says-president

Nationals of an EU country or one of the Schengen Area associated countries are free to enter the European Union, irrespective of the purpose of their stay and not only to return to their home. These people do not need to produce a negative Test before entering the Grand Duchy. Nationals of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican/Holy See are also free to enter the European Union, irrespective of the purpose of their stay and not only to return to their home. These people do not need to produce a negative Test before entering the Grand Duchy either. Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 31 March 2021  (inclusive).     https://web.archive.org/web/20201231203045/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

It should be noted that from 1 January 2021, these restrictions also apply to third-country nationals residing in the United Kingdom, including UK nationals who do not fall under the provisions of the Withdrawal Agreement (see FAQs).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103224749/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

The first people to be vaccinated are health professionals and staff in hospitals, as well as ambulance drivers, staff in residential care facilities for the elderly and in care and support networks, and people living in these facilities. On Thursday 28 and 29 December, around 800 people from the hospital sector will be vaccinated, and 200 people per hospital establishment for acute treatments respectively. On Wednesday 30 December, staff from senior citizens' homes will be vaccinated - with an additional 400 vaccinations planned. In addition, paramedics transporting COVID-19 patients were offered vaccination during these three days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103233531/https://gouvernement.lu/en/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2020/12-decembre/28-vaccin-covid.html

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety    The on-site study process shall take place only in kindergartens and from grade 1 to grade 4. An area of at least 3 square meters per pupil must be provided. From 3 December, kindergarten employees shall wear masks at all times. From 4 January, both pupils and teachers shall wear masks during lessons and outside the learning process at schools.  The completion of higher education, adult continuous vocational training, vocational in-service training, and non-formal education programs shall be held only remotely. On the other hand, practical skills that cannot be acquired remotely can be acquired in person only individually - one teacher with one student.  The practical parts of interest education can take place in person only individually. Practices of choirs and wind instruments are not allowed in person.
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety  rom 3 December, 15 square meters per visitor must be provided in shops and service points. Information on the number of people allowed must be clearly visible at the entrance. Economic service providers, shops and event organizers must ensure that people who do not wear a face mask or do it incorrectly are not allowed on the premises and services are not provided to those who do not comply with epidemiological safety requirements.  All shops and the shopping centers, regardless of the total sales area, shall be open on weekdays as usual. However, only pharmacies, including veterinary pharmacies, may operate on Saturdays, Sundays, and public holidays, while only groceries (except alcohol and cigarettes), hygiene products and fuel may be sold in shops. On weekdays, everyone works with the same quadrature constraints. On Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays, sales points may not be open, except - pharmacies (including veterinary) and shops selling food (except alcohol and cigarettes), hygiene products, fuel. Subject to epidemiological safety measures, beauty care providers - hairdressing and manicure service providers - may operate. Libraries are allowed on site to loan out books and, subject to epidemiological security measures, museums are still available to visitors.
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety  As of 3 December, principle 2 + 2 shall be observed by everyone in Latvia in their daily routine - two meters, two people. So, a distance of two meters must be observed and meetings must be limited to two people. Until 11 January, operation of all cultural sites, exhibitions, as well as fairs, including Christmas markets, shall be prohibited. In the meantime, no more than 20% of the maximum number of people may be present at the same time in places of religious activity.  Organized meetings, pickets and marches are still allowed, but a maximum of 25 people is allowed to attend, subject to epidemiological safety requirements.
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety  On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety    As of 3 December, principle 2 + 2 shall be observed by everyone in Latvia in their daily routine - two meters, two people. So, a distance of two meters must be observed and meetings must be limited to two people.  Private events shall be prohibited, except than within a single household. It is allowed to visit people who live alone and need care, observing the 2 + 2 principle.  At funerals and christening ceremonies held in urgent cases, no more than 10 people (excluding those directly involved, such as the clergy) may gather outdoors, from no more than two households, using mouth and nose covers.
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)

No closure measures. That being said:  From 7 December, in order to protect people in public transport, the number of passengers must not exceed 50% of the vehicle's capacity. If it is not possible to control the embarkation and disembarkation of passengers, the vehicle must be provided with instructions on the use of seats to ensure physical distancing. In public transport, face masks must be worn by both the driver and passengers, including children from the age of 7.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety

No changes to the policy (ends on Dec31st).   On November 3rd the government decided to introduce downtime allowance of around 70% of the monthly pay for workers affected by Covid-19 (the difference with spring is that any company (in all economic sectors) can now apply for the allowance if it’s fall in revenue exceeds 20%). Allowance is paid to a merchant in the amount of 70% of the merchant’s declared average salary for three months (August, September, October). The subsidy will be paid to the employee (employed, self-employed, and patent payers). The minimum amount of the subsidy is planned to be EUR 330 (the amount is determined in accordance with the net minimum wage in the country); it is planned to pay another EUR 50 for each dependent; the maximum amount of the subsidy is EUR 1000 (net). At the same time, it is stipulated that the aid paid to employees must not exceed 80% of gross salary.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207043641/https://www.mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/vitenbergs-downtime-allowance-and-allowance-employee-salary-subsidies-will-be-available

Broad economic relief and support available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113092303/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/economics/entrepreneurs/support-entrepreneurs    In spring, 2020, those debt reliefs that were offered to households and businesses were announced based on EBA guidelines or private initiatives from the banks. Measures for households and firms were announced centrally by the Finance Latvia association. The deadline to apply for these reliefs ended as of September 30. Legislative moratorium (announced by government) is viable only for student loans. As of now, even with new EBA guidelines announced last week, there are no new centralized programmes to apply.
Coordinated public campaign still ongoing. Specific websites in place as well as information on social media among others:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201207044619/https://covid19.gov.lv/en

No new changes. The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova continues through the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021.

No policy changes for this time period, further restrictions will be in effect from 21 December for winter break activities from Decision No 37 of Moldova's National Extraordinary Public Health Commission from 11 December 2020, excerpt:  1. The following things are established, in order to boost the measures of prevention and control of the COVID-19 infection in the general secondary education institutions and the early education ones:    1.1. Carrying out of online classes at the education disciplines, according to the framework plan for the forms of the primary school, gymnasium and lyceum on the period 21-24 December 2020.    1.2. Suspension, starting from 14 December 2020, of the extracurricular activities (sports circles and sections) at the headquarters of the education institutions and their carrying out online.  1.3. The education activities on the occasion of the winter holidays in schools and kindergartens will be organized in classes/groups with the observance of the social distance, with the presence of only teachers/educators from the concerned class/group. The classes and groups will be provided with proper conditions for the hygiene/disinfection of hands.     1.4. The education institution’s employees, as well as the pupils of the gymnasium and lyceum classes will compulsorily wear protection masks.       https://web.archive.org/web/20201213215125/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2020/12/11/20009882

On 8 December, additional restrictions on hours of some types of businesses were implemented:  The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled that, starting from today, the activity of servicing in all public nourishment units, including at those placed at the points for the sale of oil products, in commercial centres, airports, international ports, should be ceased at night, namely in the time interval 22:00-7:00.  Also, the (CNESP) members established that the public authorities subordinated to the government should work according to a special working regime, in the conditions of the pandemic situation in Moldova. Thus, the public sector employees will start their working day at 7:30 and will end it at 16:00, with a 30- minutes dinner break. The provision enters into force starting from 8 December and will be revised depending on the epidemiological situation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213221108/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-rules-ban-service-public

"Authorities in Moldova are maintaining international entry restrictions as of Dec. 7 to combat the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Authorities designate all countries with COVID-19 infection rates of over 100 per 100,000 population as "red" or high-risk locations. Most travelers from red locations are prohibited from entering Moldova, excluding Moldovan citizens and residents and their immediate family members, individuals with a work or study permit for Moldova, individuals in transit, and individuals traveling for urgent reasons. All permitted arrivals from red countries must self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival. As of Dec. 7, 63 countries are designated as red locations, including Canada, France, Germany, Romania, Russia, Spain, Ukraine, the UK, and the US; the full list can be found on the Ministry of Health website."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103132254/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/410051/moldova-covid-19-related-state-of-emergency-in-effect-as-of-dec-7-update-10

No new changes. The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova continues through the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021.

No policy change. The state of emergency continues until the 15th of December.    "Domestically, a state of emergency is in effect until at least Jan. 15. Bars, restaurants, and other catering facilities must close from 2200-0700; from Dec. 8, all public offices will close at 1600. Private gatherings of up to 50 people are permitted but must take place away from schools, hospitals, and other public institutions. Most businesses are permitted to reopen provided they adhere to strict health and safety measures. Facemasks are mandatory in enclosed public spaces and on public transport. People over 63 years of age must remain in their accommodation except for essential purposes."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103132254/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/410051/moldova-covid-19-related-state-of-emergency-in-effect-as-of-dec-7-update-10    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103132331/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Moldova joined COVAX in August 2020 and therefore, once vaccines are available it is expected that the following policy will be in place:  Thus, based on the fact that the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunizations, through the COVAX platform ensures coverage of 20% of the country's population free of charge, the following target groups have been identified: medical workers; adults over 65 years of age and comorbidities (high risk group); beneficiaries of temporary or long-term placement centers; people with comorbidities; social workers; workers in the field of education and those in security bodies.  Subsequently, depending on the availability of the vaccine, other groups of the population will be vaccinated, which are equally extremely important.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213220911/https://www.gavi.org/sites/default/files/covid/pr/COVAX_CA_COIP_List_COVAX_PR_24-11.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213221805/https://en.publika.md/moldova-made-a-request-to-covax-platform-for-covid-19-vaccine--_2662393.html

Authorities in Poland have decided to prolong the ban on international flights previously imposed on nine countries, until December 31, 2020, due to the Coronavirus situation in their territories.    Citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, Montenegro, Armenia, Jordan, Kosovo, North Macedonia, Serbia and the United States (excluding Illinois and New York), will be prohibited from entering Poland until the end of this month, SchengenVisaInfo.com reports.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201208193659/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/poland-prolongs-flight-ban-on-nine-countries-to-december-31/

Any person entering the country via organised transport is subject to a 10 day quarantine.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101210448/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przedluzamy-etap-odpowiedzialnosci-i-wprowadzamy-dodatkowe-ograniczenia

The Polish Vaccine roll out begins on the 30th of December. Medics, social workers, uniformed services, teachers and senior citizens are the first groups to get the jab (groups A and C). "Extremely high risk" and "very high risk" counties:  - On business days, commercial establishments must close until 22:00. Restaurants, cultural facilities and sports facilities must close until 22:30 (catering establishments can operate until 01:00, but only for home deliveries).  - On weekends and holidays, commercial establishments can only operate between 08:00 and 13:00. - - The catering can work after that time, but only for 'take-away' and home deliveries.    "High risk" counties:  - Commercial establishments must close until 22:00. Restaurants, cultural facilities and sports facilities must close until 22:30 (catering establishments can operate until 01:00, but only for home deliveries).    "Moderate risk" counties  - Commercial establishments cannot open before 10:00 am, with the exception of hairdressers, barbers, beauty salons, restaurants and the like, cafeterias, tea houses and the like, driving schools and technical vehicle inspection centers, as well as gyms and gyms.  - Most commercial establishments are closed between 8 pm and 11 pm, and the closing time, within this interval, as well as the opening time, may be fixed by the mayors of the city councils, subject to a favorable opinion from the local health authority. and security forces.  - Restaurants have to close at 1:00 am (with new admissions until midnight), with their capacity limited to 50% of capacity. Groups are limited to six people (unless they belong to the same household), except in establishments located within 300 meters of a school and in the food courts of shopping centers, where they are limited to four people (if not from household).

For municipalities with a “ high ” risk level , in addition to the measures applied to the entire continental territory:  - Prohibition of circulation on public roads between 11 pm and 5 am;  - Action to monitor compliance with mandatory teleworking ;  Maintenance of the establishment's opening hours (10 pm, except restaurants and cultural facilities at 10:30 pm).    For “ very high ” and “ extremely high ” municipalities , in addition to the measures applied to the entire national territory, the following also apply:  - Prohibition of circulation on public roads between 11 pm and 5 am on weekdays ;  - Prohibition of circulation on public roads on Saturdays and Sundays between 1 pm and 5 am;  - Prohibition of circulation on public roads on December 1 and 8 between 1 pm and 5 am;    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213002105/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/renovacao-do-estado-de-emergencia/

Authorities in Portugal permit entry for travelers from the EU and Schengen Area countries, the UK, Australia, Canada, China, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, and Uruguay; these arrivals do not require a COVID-19 test unless their final destination is the Azores or Madeira. Travel from other countries remains prohibited, except for limited essential reasons, including EU citizens and residents returning home, reuniting with family, and commuting to essential work or study. All such arrivals are required to submit a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before boarding; however, Portuguese nationals and residents may arrange to take the test on arrival at their own expense.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213000026/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/409031/portugal-authorities-extend-state-of-emergency-through-dec-23-amid-ongoing-covid-19-activity-update-22

The Government presented yesterday, December 3, the Vaccination Plan against Covid-19. According to the document, the vaccine, which should arrive in Portugal as early as January, will be universal, free and optional, and will be made available to the population according to the characteristics approved by the European Medicines Agency. Three phases are planned for the implementation of the vaccination plan against Covid-19 in 2021, which will accompany the pace of availability of vaccines.    1st phase - It is intended for people over 50 with associated pathologies; residents and professionals in nursing homes and long-term care units; Health professionals; armed forces, security forces and critical services professionals. At this stage, approximately 950 thousand people should be vaccinated.    2nd phase - In this phase 1.8 million people over 65 years of age and around 900 thousand with associated pathologies and over 50 years will be vaccinated.    3rd phase - The rest of the population. The groups in this phase will be reviewed according to the pace of delivery of the vaccines    Vaccine administration  The first phase of vaccination will be administered at the approximately 1,200 vaccination points that are usual in health centers, in homes and long-term care units.  The health centers will be destined to 400 thousand people over 50 years old and associated comorbidities, while users and home professionals will be vaccinated there by the resident nursing teams.  The vaccine will also be administered to health professionals and essential services in the field of occupational medicine.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213003729/https://www.sns.gov.pt/noticias/2020/12/04/plano-de-vacinacao-contra-a-covid-19/

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours. The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities. Also, the Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance).  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/Bv8vi , https://archive.fo/cUlEp and https://web.archive.org/web/20201120195835/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities. Also, the Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance). Between 6th of December (5 AM) and 7th of December (1 AM), there are no more in place restrictions regarding movement due to National Elections.   Link: https://archive.fo/wip/Bv8vi , https://archive.fo/cUlEp and https://archive.fo/T7Aib

The Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through Decision 58/10.12.20) of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance). The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities. On 20th of November, The National Committee for Emergency Situations published Decision no.55 regarding the approval of the list of countries/areas of epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on persons arriving in Romania from them. Also, there are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions).  According to the Decision 56/4.12.2020 of The National Committee for Emergency Situations, the list of countries of high epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on the persons arriving in Romania from them was approved.  Link: https://archive.fo/9KkOQ, https://archive.fo/lIjB1, https://archive.fo/pUara and https://archive.fo/s1GX6

The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers.  According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/hVM21
