Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. Also, “Datelazi.ro” (Updated data) project was released pro-bon by Code for Romania in partnership with the Government of Romania through the Authority for the Digitalization of Romania, containing data and information provided by the Government of Romania.   Links: https://archive.fo/cUlEp, https://archive.fo/klswT , https://archive.fo/Vi0vG and https://archive.fo/X428Q

According to the Ministry of Health, the units that are accredited by the Ministry of Health to perform the diagnosis by RT-PCR have the obligation to provide priority diagnosis for patients in health facilities, suspects in epidemiological investigations, and people at risk, according to the methodology of the National Institute of Public Health – National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases.   Link: https://archive.fo/6K5UM

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

At the proposal of the Ministry of Health, the Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/C61Wh

The Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles, and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency. Also, the chairman of the National Coordinating Committee for Vaccination Activities against COVID-19 announced that the National Vaccine Storage Center is ready to receive vaccines after the European Medicines Agency issues the conditional marketing authorization. There are three stages of vaccination: first for health care workers, second -for the population at risk, for essential staff and the last stage – for the general population.  Link: https://archive.fo/KYZQL and https://archive.fo/KYZQL

The Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles, and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency. There are three stages of vaccination: first for health care workers, second -for the population at risk, for essential staff and the last stage – for the general population. On 27th of December, the first stage started with the first 10 000 doses of vaccines in all 10 infectious disease hospitals on the front lines in the fight against COVID-19.  Link: https://archive.fo/KYZQL, https://archive.fo/wip/C61Wh and https://archive.fo/wip/pnsuB

Further restrictions were introduced on 4 Dec, with a number of workplace sectors required to close on weekends (5 pm on Friday to 5 am on Monday). This includes restaurants, shopping centres, casinos, hair salons and sports facilities. All of the above are allowed to continue open between 5 am and 5 pm on weekdays. An exception is made to food delivery services, which are allowed to function 24/7.     "Grocery stores, shops, retail facilities, as well as newsagents, kiosks and the like, where, as a rule, customers do not enter the facility in order to make the purchase, can work on weekdays and weekends until 9 pm.    Pharmacies and gas stations (fuel sales) can work non-stop, every day without restrictions.    Open-air green markets will also work on weekends from 6 am. to 3 pm."    "Medical centres and laboratories can operate throughout the day, including weekends."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207201946/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/164342/tighter-anti-coronavirus-measures-in-effect-as-of-tomorrow.php

On 04 December, State Secretary of the Ministry of Health Mirsad Djerlek stated today that mass vaccination in Serbia is expected in the first quarter of 2021, and that a certain amount of vaccines will arrive by the end of 2020.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219184423/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/164417/mass-vaccination-in-first-quarter-of-2021.php

On 18 December, Minister of Health Zoran Loncar stated today in Novi Sad that the first doses of Pfizer vaccine will arrive in Serbia on Monday or Tuesday, adding that slightly less than 5,000 doses will arrive in the first tranche and that they will be received by users of nursing homes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219183423/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165232/first-doses-of-pfizer-vaccine-in-serbia-on-monday.php

On 30 December 2020, Minister of Health Zlatibor Loncar stated in Novi Sad that the vaccination of health workers began today and that those working in infectious diseases clinics and emergency centres have already been vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102195559/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165717/vaccination-of-health-workers-begins.php

With effect from 7 December 2020, where the operating conditions so permit and if the founder so decides:  resumes school teaching in primary schools in the fifth to ninth grades, secondary schools, primary arts schools and language schools for pupils and listeners who fulfil the conditions set out in point B.1. resolutions of the Government of the Slovak Republic No. 760 of 4 December 2020 and in decree of the Public Health Office of the Slovak Republic No. 32/2020 V. v. SR ordering measures at risk of public health to prove negative results of the test for COVID-19 disease before entering the premises of schools, and restore the operation of school facilities for pupils as referred to in point 1.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214004111/https://korona.gov.sk/obnova-vyucovania-na-skolach-od-11-12-2020/
No change.

School resumes after 8 January, no changes noted at this time, except that they are closed for holiday break.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102205658/https://korona.gov.sk/zakaz-vychadzania/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102210232/https://www.slov-lex.sk/pravne-predpisy/SK/ZZ/2020/427/20201229  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102210902/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From 11 December, the Slovak Republic will enter a lockdown additional restrictions will be in place for some sectors:  December 11, 2020: the outdoor terraces of restaurants, cafés and similar facilities will be closed. Takeaways should be preserved. Driving schools will switch to remote classes.  December 14, 2020: stricter conditions will be implemented for hotels and ski centres: every visitor older than 10 years of age will be required to show a negative rapid or PCR test result no older than 72 hours.  In hotels, it will not be possible to eat and drink in the shared spaces.  In terms of ski lifts, only one person or people from the same household will be allowed to be on one chairlift or in one cable car.  December 21, 2020: School holiday begins and shops except for essential ones (grocery stores etc.) will be closed. The shops will stay closed for three weeks in each district, i.e. at least until January 10. It is not clear yet when schools will reopen.  December 28, 2020: Regular testing in companies with more than 500 employees will begin, so that they can return to work.  No curfew or mobility restrictions will be applied during the lockdown.  The restrictions will be lifted in those areas where the epidemic situation allows it.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214004241/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=223&Itemid=144  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214004530/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22551152/the-central-crisis-staff-agreed-on-lockdown.html?ref=av-center
No change.

Existing measures remain in place, on 29 December the state of emergency was extended 40 more days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102205658/https://korona.gov.sk/zakaz-vychadzania/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102210232/https://www.slov-lex.sk/pravne-predpisy/SK/ZZ/2020/427/20201229  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102210902/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On 26 December, the first person received a vaccine and roll-out out 4 additional hospitals was scheduled to begin 27 December. Four waves of vaccination are planned:  1. healthcare staff, employees of nursing homes, critical infrastructure;  2. people older than 65 years, people suffering from chronic diseases, clients of nursing homes;  3. marginalised groups, homeless people, asylum seekers, teachers;  4. everybody older than 18 years (voluntary principle).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102214442/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22562138/vaccines-have-arrived.html

From 7 December until 6 January, high schools will be closed. On 3 December, the Public Health Agency issued a 'recommendation' to close all high schools (gymnasieskolor - ages 16-19) for a month and move all classes online. This dose not include exams which cannot be taken at a distance.     In line with the Interpretation Guide on C1, I have coded this as '2', since "if the situation is that all schools are closed ... then that would count as a full closure".    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207153005/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/contentassets/27a3b8becacc47edbfa51273b4931886/beslut-2020-12-03-rekommendation-om-delvis-stangning-och-overgang-till-fjarr-eller-distansundervisning-gymnasieskolan.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20201207154159/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin

High schools are closed from 7 December until 6 January. On 3 December, the Public Health Agency issued a 'recommendation' to close all high schools (gymnasieskolor - ages 16-19) for a month and move all classes online. This does not include exams which cannot be taken at a distance.     In line with the Interpretation Guide on C1, I have coded this as '2', since "if the situation is that all schools are closed ... then that would count as a full closure".    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207153005/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/contentassets/27a3b8becacc47edbfa51273b4931886/beslut-2020-12-03-rekommendation-om-delvis-stangning-och-overgang-till-fjarr-eller-distansundervisning-gymnasieskolan.pdf    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207154159/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin

The Public Health Agency has 'recommended' to close all upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor - ages 16-19) and move all classes online for the period of 7 December 2020 to 24 January 2021. This does not include exams which cannot be taken at a distance.     In line with the Interpretation Guide on C1, I have coded this as '2', since "if the situation is that all schools are closed ... then that would count as a full closure".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104153119/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin

The ban on public gatherings of over 8 people remains in effect, meaning in practice that all public events have to be cancelled.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104153454/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

For public gatherings, there is a ban on gatherings over 8 people. The Public Health Agency "strongly recommends" to also adhere to these requirements in private.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164126/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    In the words of home minister Mikael Damberg: "The recommendations from the agencies aren't some kind of tips for the public -- they should be followed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214162622/https://www.thelocal.se/20201211/sweden-to-send-mass-text-banging-home-christmas-covid-rules

In force from 14 December, the Public Health Agency replaced its regional advice with national regulations and general advice, in light of the upcoming Christmas holidays. This includes the recommendation to limit the number of encounters and spend time in a "small circle" and avoid being part of several different groups, in order to reduce the number of close contacts as much as possible. "The fewer, the better." A smaller circle ["mindre krets"] is "a few people, but it is not possible to say an exact number. Who and how many are included in the circle can vary based on each individual's life situation. For some it may be some close friends, for others the immediate family."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/

The ban on public gatherings of over 8 people remains in effect. The Public Health Agency has "strongly recommended" to also adhere to these requirements in private.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104153454/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    In the words of home minister Mikael Damberg: "The recommendations from the agencies aren't some kind of tips for the public -- they should be followed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214162622/https://www.thelocal.se/20201211/sweden-to-send-mass-text-banging-home-christmas-covid-rules

Public transport operates at reduced capacity, has reduced the number of bookable seats and recommends using a different means of transport if there are no more bookable seats available for a specific departure time.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214165754/https://www.sj.se/sv/om/om-sj/senaste-info-coronavirus-o-tagresor.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214165848/https://www.trafikverket.se/om-oss/var-verksamhet/sa-har-jobbar-vi-med/trafikverkets-forhallningssatt-till-coronaviruset/

In force from 14 December, the Public Health Agency replaced its regional advice with national regulations and general advice, in light of the upcoming Christmas holidays. These are divided into rules and advice aimed at individuals, with an emphasis on personal responsibility, and rules and advice aimed at businesses. Re public transport, for individuals, the recommendation is to limit the use of public transport as much as possible. Public transport companies should: 1) run schedules in such a way as to reduce the risk of congestion; 2) limit the number of passengers per vehicle; 3) inform their passengers on how they can reduce the risk of spreading the virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/

No change since last entry. The Public Health Agency recommends to limit the use of public transport as much as possible. "You should avoid traveling by public transport and other public transport where a seat reservation is not offered. In the first place, you should use other modes of transport, such as walking, cycling or driving your own car."  Its recommendations to public transport companies include: 1) run schedules in such a way as to reduce the risk of congestion; 2) limit the number of passengers per vehicle; 3) inform their passengers on how they can reduce the risk of spreading the virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104154139/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/i-kollektivtrafiken/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104154249/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/
No change in policy since last entry

This includes the recommendation to stay at home with symptoms and work from home as much as possible.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/

In force from 14 December, the Public Health Agency replaced its regional advice with national regulations and general advice, in light of the upcoming Christmas holidays. This means that previous regional advice that explicit recommended against internal travel is no longer in force. I have not changed the code (only from T to G), because the new nation-wide advice, though less explicit compared to the regional advice, still seeks to limit travel incl travel between regions, e.g. "think through whether planned trips are really necessary to carry out".     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/

In addition to the general temporary entry ban for non-EU non-essential travellers, as of 22 December, an additional entry ban was introduced for travellers from the UK and Denmark. The entry ban from the UK is due to the spread and mutation of COVID-19 that have been reported there. The entry ban from Denmark is mainly to reduce the risk of congestion and the spread of the virus in shopping centres and restaurants in Skåne County.    Exempt from the entry ban are Swedish citizens, people transporting goods, and people living in Denmark and working across the border in Sweden.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201218171409/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/12/temporary-entry-ban-extended-until-31-march-2021-and-amended-due-to-brexit/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201230204915/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/12/ban-on-entry-into-sweden-from-the-united-kingdom-and-denmark/

The general temporary entry ban for non-EU non-essential travellers as well as travellers from the UK and Denmark remains in place.     As of 1 January 2021, people exempt from the ban and travelling from the UK are required to present a negative test result at the most 72 hours before arriving in Sweden.     This requirement does not apply to those transporting goods – who may therefore enter the country without presenting a negative test result. This is to avoid impeding the transport of essential goods, such as pharmaceuticals or medical equipment.    Nor does the requirement apply to Swedish citizens, who always have the right to enter Sweden. However, the recommendation of the Public Health Agency of Sweden still applies, i.e. that everyone who has been in the UK should get tested for COVID-19 immediately upon arrival to Sweden, remain at home and get tested again after five days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104160031/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/12/negative-covid-19-test-result-required-for-entry-into-sweden-from-uk/

There is currently no regulation that requires the use of facemasks, but the Public Health Agency has announced that it will produce a national guideline on the use of facemasks in public transport on weekdays before 7 January 2021, when most people return to work or school after the holidays.     The public transport providers will need to inform travelers about the recommendation to use facemasks and should provide facemasks free of charge for those travellers who do not bring their own.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201221201620/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2020/december/ytterligare-atgarder-for-att-bromsa-smitta-och-skydda-halsa/

Currently no policy, but from 7 January, the Public Health Agency recommends the use of face masks during rush hour (7-9 am + 4-6 pm) in public transport. The recommendation applies to everyone born in 2004 and earlier. Individuals who for medical reasons cannot wear mouth guards are excluded from the recommendation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104161220/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/om-sjukdomen-och-smittspridning/smittspridning/munskydd/
https://web.archive.org/web/20201214222935/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/
No change in policy since last entry: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221200714/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/

The first vaccinations took place on 27 December. The Public Health Agency has recommended different phases for the vaccination, according to the need for protection of respective groups. During Phase 1, which started on 27 December, elderly living in care homes or receive home care under the Social Services Act, staff working directly with these people, and adults living with someone belonging to this risk group are eligible. Phase 2 is expected to start in February 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104161641/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2020/december/vaccinationerna-i-sverige-har-inletts/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104162056/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/rekommendationer-for-vaccination-mot-covid-19/

There has been no significant change since the last data entry. The government continues to require many business activities to remain closed. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    Grocery stores are open. "Recreational facilities, non-essential shops, bars and restaurants, entertainment facilities, sports, spa and beauty facilities, and mosques are closed to the public."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

The government continues to cancel public events. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "Recreational facilities, non-essential shops, bars and restaurants, entertainment facilities, sports, spa and beauty facilities, and mosques are closed to the public."    "Mosques and places of pilgrimage are closed and large gatherings are restricted."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

"Additionally, while there is no official ban on public gatherings, authorities in Ashgabat have deactivated ATMs in shopping centers and semi-enclosed market areas, including the Terkinsky bazaar, to prevent crowds from congregating. All persons are required to observe social distancing of at least 1 meter (3 feet) and wear protective face coverings in public."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064217/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/423761/turkmenistan-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-international-and-domestic-travel-restrictions-until-at-least-jan-31-update-8    "Recreational facilities, non-essential shops, bars and restaurants, entertainment facilities, sports, spa and beauty facilities, and mosques are closed to the public."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064017/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

The government continues to limit the services of public transport. There has been no significant change since the last date input. The government continues to not require people to stay at home. There are rumours that a lockdown might have been introduced since 1 November 2020, but the source is unofficial and cannot be confirmed. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201116183946/https://for.kg/news-674059-en.html    https://www.barrons.com/news/turkmen-leader-opens-new-hospital-insists-country-virus-free-01605340808
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to restrict internal movement. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "Traffic police check points have been established around major population centres, including Ashgabat, and road users may be subject to temperature screening."    "Domestic flights remain operational, but with a reduced service. Passengers are subject to temperature checks."    "[N]ewspapers report that a COVID-19 test result is required for boarding domestic flights."    "Rail services are suspended."    "Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes. There are some reports of restrictions on interstate travel."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus
No changes found from last announcements.

"Security forces have erected checkpoints on roads entering Ashgabat. Checkpoints have also been reported on highways in Balkan, Mary, Lebap, and Dashoguz provinces, where health screenings have been carried out. Special permits are required for travel within or between provinces."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064217/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/423761/turkmenistan-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-international-and-domestic-travel-restrictions-until-at-least-jan-31-update-8

The government continues to close its border. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "All international commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been cancelled and land borders are closed to passenger traffic. Some press reporting indicates that international flight restrictions are expected to continue through January 1, 2020."    "Commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan are suspended. Occasional, tightly controlled, charter flights are the only means of entering or leaving the country by air."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No changes found from last announcements.

"All international scheduled commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been suspended.    At present, entry to Turkmenistan is prohibited except for Turkmen nationals and accredited diplomats, permanently registered foreigners and some employees of international companies and organisations"    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064916/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/entry-requirements    "As part of ongoing efforts to limit the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19), authorities in Turkmenistan have extended their suspensions of international flights until at least Jan. 31. Domestic rail and bus services also remain suspended until at least Jan. 31. All land borders with Afghanistan, Iran, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan remain closed until further notice. Only Turkmen nationals, permanent residents, diplomats, and workers in critical industries and key infrastructure are permitted to enter the country. All arrivals must undergo a 14-day quarantine in a state-run facility. While freight traffic is generally allowed to transit the border, Turkmen authorities have previously restricted cross-border freight traffic without warning or explanation. All persons departing the country must be in possession of a negative COVID-19 test certificate, signed within the previous 24 hours."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064217/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/423761/turkmenistan-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-international-and-domestic-travel-restrictions-until-at-least-jan-31-update-8
The government continues to not offer any income support.
No changes found from last announcements.
The government continues to not offer any debt/contract relief.
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to deny the existence of any COVID case in the country, but there are coordinated public information campaigns in place.     "The Government of Turkmenistan’s Ministry of Health has established a COVID-19 hotline (tel. +993 12 73 9535) where citizens may receive information about the virus, including prevention and treatment, in both Russian and Turkmen languages."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to not implement any testing policy since it continues to deny the presence of COVID in the country. However, according to the US Embassy in Turkmenistan, "COVID-19 testing is offered in Ashgabat at Jemgyyetcilik Saglygy we Iymit Merkezi (the Virology Laboratory of the Public Health and Nutrition Center) on Gorgoly 84, Ashgabat. The test costs 100 manat for citizens of Turkmenistan and $43 for foreign citizens." Whether citizens of Turkmenistan can actually access the COVID test is unclear.    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to not implement any contact tracing measures. No changes found from last announcements.

Starting with 30th of December, all travelers who arrive in Turkey through air, land or sea will be asked to present a negative PCR test result document issued 72 ours prior to arrival. Those who fail to do so at the border gate or seaport will be quarantined in the address to where they are going. Travelers who arrived in Turkey from United Kingdom, Denmark or South Africa in the past 10 days will be asked to present a negative test result done within the past 72 hours, and also will be required to quarantine in the address to where they are going.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/symcM

Adaptive quarantine in place till 30 December 2020.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201219130935/https:/www.kmu.gov.ua/en/tag/ohorona-zdorovya?type=all&tag=Healthcare&from=30.11.2020&till=09.12.2020    Intensified quarantine was announced for the period of 8-24 January 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201218210819/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/uryad-zaprovadiv-posilenij-karantin-z-8-do-24-sichnya

From 19 December 2020, new restrictions will apply throughout Ukraine.   Acc. to these new restrictions it is forbidden:  - Carrying out mass events (performances, holiday concerts) in educational institutions with the participation of children from more than one group/class and in the presence of visitors.  - Carrying out festive events, banquets, master classes, public events in public catering establishments and entertainment facilities.  - Reception of visitors in museums, exhibitions, galleries if there are more than 1 visitor per 10m2.  - Operation of public catering establishments from 22:00 to 7:00 (except for delivery of takeaway orders). Payment transactions are prohibited after 22:00. During the night of December 31– January 1 the work of restaurants and cafes will be allowed until 01:00.  - Conducting religious events indoors upon condition that there will be present more than 1 person per 5 square meters; religious events open-air not keeping the requirement of maintaining physical distance 1.5 meters between those present.    Restrictions that continue to be in force (what is still forbidden):  • Staying in transport and public places without a mask, being outside without documents. • Unauthorized leave of the observation place. • Carrying out of mass cultural, sports, social, advertising and other actions in which more than 20 persons take part and not preserving physical distance 1.5 meters between participants (with some exceptions). • Operation of cinemas and cultural facilities with more than 50% occupancy per hall. • Carriage of more passengers in passenger transport than the number of seats (except metro). • Work of discos, night clubs and operation of public catering establishments with the organization of leisure. • Not abiding the demand to preserve a physical distance of 2 meters between the tables and to place a maximum number of 4 people at one table. • The work of business entities in which employees are not provided with masks, no markings are applied to the distance of 1.5 meters between customers, and visitors not properly wearing personal protective equipment. • Crossing the border for foreigners without an existing insurance policy (with some exceptions). • Activities of accommodation facilities (except hotels). • Visiting by a group of more than 20 persons of educational institutions, except for preschool, general secondary, out-of-school and specialized education institutions. • Visiting preschool, general secondary, out-of-school, sports and art education institutions when more than 50% of students and staff of the educational institution stay in self-isolation. • Carrying out planned hospitalization (with exceptions). • Operation of gyms, fitness centers and museums, if they allow more than 1 person per 20 m2. • Visiting places of temporary detention of persons, places of temporary stay of foreigners and stateless persons, accommodation places for refugees. • Crossing the checkpoints with the temporarily occupied territories of separate areas of Donetsk and Luhansk regions (ORDLO) and Crimea by foreigners without an existing insurance policy (with some exceptions). • Visits to social protection institutions with the stay of persons of certain categories (persons of senior age, war veterans, people with disabilities, mental disorders, etc.).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201220102241/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/uryadom-zaprovadzheno-perelik-karantinnih-obmezhen-yaki-diyatimut-z-19-grudnya-2020-roku-na-vsij-teritoriyi-ukrayini

No evidence of a policy change. Coordinated public information campaign provided by the Ministry of Health.  source:  https://archive.vn/Lg5oM

Diagnostics will be carried out only in cases that correspond to the epidemiological and clinical definition of the disease specified in the WHO recommendations. Testing will be carried out in virological laboratories of the system of the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Uzbekistan. It is impossible to buy a test system for independent use.  source:  https://archive.vn/Lg5oM
No evidence of a policy change.
Masks are required on public transportation and in taxis.  Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201212191648/https://uz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Masks must be worn in public.  source:  https://archive.vn/eZ6Zt

No evidence of a policy change. Vaccines are currently not available for citizens of Uzbekistan. However, the government has applied for 2 million doses of vaccine through COVAX.   source:  https://archive.vn/Vif6P
